data.title: Sir Edward Heath: Timeline of life and career
data.meta_description: Ted Heath rose from humble origins to the highest office in the land but allegations about his private life now threaten to tarnish his legacy
data.text:
Ted Heath, aged 4 (Camera Press)

July 1916 – Edward Heath is born in Broadstairs, Kent. The son of a carpenter he wins an organ scholarship to study at Balliol College, Oxford.

At Oxford in the 1930's with mother Edith (Camera Press)

February 1950 – He is elected as Conservative MP for Bexley in Kent.

October 1959 – Is given his first government job as Minister for Labour in Harold Macmillan’s cabinet.

With Harold MacMillan, left, in 1963 (PA)

July 1965 – Following defeat the previous year, Sir Edward Heath is elected leader of the Conservative Party and at 49 becomes its youngest ever leader.

March 1966 - The Tories lose the general election to Harold Wilson’s Labour party, but Sir Edward remains in post as leader.

Ted Heath with Margaret Thatcher in 1970 (PA)

January 1972 – Signs treaty taking Britain into what will one day become the EU. Later the same year he passes a bill making EU law enforceable in the UK.

Polling his vote in the 1974 General Election (Camera Press)

October 1974 – The Heath administration is dogged by industrial strife and rising violence in Northern Ireland and after a Spring election results in a hung parliament and Autumn vote sees Labour win a narrow victory.

February 1975 – Margaret Thatcher is elected leader of the Conservative Party and Sir Edward returns to the backbenches after declining to serve under her.

With Jimmy Savile in 1980 (PA)

1990s – A criminal trial is allegedly halted after the defendant threatens to expose Sir Edward as a paedophile. According to a whistleblower, who was serving with the force at the time, senior officers quietly dropped the case in order to protect the former Prime Minister. This allegation was later denied.

Conducting his last Christmas carol concert, 2000 (PA)

October 2000 – After 51-years as an MP, including more than quarter of a century on the backbenches, Sir Edward retires and moves full time to his home next to Salisbury Cathedral, from where he indulges in his passion for sailing and music.

Arundells in Salisbury (Eddie Mulholland/The Telegraph)
